Fields.DialogueText: De Ruyter? Are you in here? I need to ask you abou-
Ah! Kapitein, could I trouble you to move for just a moment?
-- Is that a microscope?
Inderdaad. And you cast a long shadow.

Fields.MenuText: My reputation precedes me.
I thought microscopes had light bulbs.
Well, I'll get out of your hair.

Fields.DialogueText: Nee, dat hoeft niet. I'm almost done.
They do. But I'm looking at fine detail, here.
Doesn't it always?
Well, I'm happy to let you look, but there's something we need to talk about. It's not urgent, but...
But it could be, potentially?
Mmm. Not more urgent than your studies.
Dank je, Kapitein.
*ALARM*
Helaas, this *is* more urgent. See you on the bridge?
Whenever you're ready.
@BATTLE
What is it you wanted to talk to me about?
Well, before we get into the heavy stuff... I'm curious. What were you doing with that microscope?
My microscope- oh!
It's nothing too important, as of yet. I was looking at the German uniform patch we pulled from that Morgana the other day. Call it... post hoc verification.
After the fact, hm. Well, I won't stop you. Your insights are always  valuable.
Glad you trust them, Kapitein.
But I'm curious. What's this less-than-urgent thing you want to discuss?
Well, we just recently received a report... they're planning on commending me for our work against the Rotterdam Four.
Oh, that's wonderful news!

Fields.MenuText: Commending *me*. You see the problem.
There's something very important missing from that picture.
You sound too happy, considering.

Fields.DialogueText: What- Oh. I don't mind, Kapitein.
I don't, really. But thank you for your concern.
You did good work, Kapitein. That deserves its reward.
You were instrumental. You did all the legwork.
None of us can do anything alone. And they know a Kapitein's nothing without their ship.
It doesn't feel right to take credit for your achievement.
And it doesn't feel right to force them to give me credit.
*ALARM*
Unfortunately, it's time to 'achieve' more.
All in a day's work.
@BATTLE
Dat geniepige- Ugh.
What's wrong? More "post hoc?"
Something like that. I'm... corresponding with our German friends.
I see.
I regret writing *this* letter, but that's just because Deutschland's-
Ah, say no more.
She's very... evasive. And I think she wormed some things out of me that I didn't mean to tell.

Fields.MenuText: The charm offensive?
She does that.
I think you're barking up the wrong tree.

Fields.DialogueText: It was more helpful than she intended, too.
It's annoying. But I gave as good as I got.
If you can call it that. It's not *charm* she has, exactly...
... But she confirmed my suspicions, Kapitein.
Oh? How so?
Deutschland has what you might  call a fiets personality.
"Bicycle?" Ah. Kiss up, kick down. I know the type.
You remember our friend, the Kriegsmarine kapitein?
The one who sacrificed himself to save us? Yes.
He was lying. And she proved it.
How-
*ALARM*
Let's send these Morganas packing and I'll explain when we're done.
I can't wait to hear this one.
@BATTLE
... It's normally much more pleasant than this. Our countries are friendly enough.
Lody in particular is a great conversationalist.
So. The Kriegsmarine captain was lying?
Toeptoep, not so loud. I know it's wrong to speak ill of the dead.
But yes, I have reason to believe he was.
Extraordinary claims require-
Extraordinary evidence. May I finish, Kapitein?
I'll hear you out.
I looked at the uniform patch that he gave us under my microscope. I corresponded with that American Belle, Lexington-
And any other Belles I'd heard talking about Morgana forgeries.
Is that why you were talking to Deutschland?
Nee, I did that for a different reason.

Fields.MenuText: Her ... *charming* personality?
She's ... friendly with her officers?
You think she's in on ...whatever scam he was running?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't think that's quite it, but she is very... well-connected. Yes.
We understand each other.
Nee. She's awful, but I don't want to believe another Belle would...  There was a different reason.
Deutschland will defend her superior officers to the death. At least publically.
If an outsider comes to her with evidence of wrongdoing... Well. She'll get prickly.
And she got prickly?
*Intensely*. She told me a Kriegsmarine captain wouldn't lie about something like that. And I didn't make accusations.
She just jumped straight into defending him.
To be fair, it was a very stupid and obvious lie.
I'm still putting the pieces together. Help me out?
*ALARM*
Of course, Kapitein. But first, let's take these Morganas apart.
With pleasure.
@BATTLE
Curieus.
What are we talking about?
Just something I keep hearing in port.
I know what you mean. Every other joker claims to have slept with a Belle these days.
I. Uh. Ah. Well. Hm.

Fields.MenuText: Your ears went pink.
I have to wonder what that would be like...
Ah, it's just jokes. Don't take it too seriously.

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so, Kapitein.
I can't imagine it'd be too different from sleeping with any other woman, Kapitein.
Flirtations have that effect on most people, don't they?
Mmm, that was barely flirting.
Do you want it to be serious?
I have more serious things on my mind right now, Kapitein.
You should see me when I'm trying.
Well, perhaps, in the spirit of scientific inquiry...
Ah. Well. It's a wonderful offer, but.
Like what?
The *truly* worrying rumour I heard around port.
*ALARM*
Ah, the girls of the hour.
Let's send them packing. We don't want more Rotterdam Helleveegen.
@BATTLE
So, about this rumor...
Still investigating. It's something I want to be absolutely sure about.
... Even selling people to the Helleveegen.

Fields.MenuText: Whose word?

Fields.DialogueText: Nobody of rank yet, but at least three sailors in three separate ports swear they were the lucky ones of some captured crew.
So that's why you were investigating the patch.
We never did get a look at his crew, did we? Maybe there was a reason he was so adamant about pushing through the waves and reaching his destination as soon as possible.
You think he was harboring contraband below deck?
Perhaps he was worried about getting caught and was willing to risk his life to avoid jail time. Pure speculation on my part, but...
Well, keep it under your hat for now. It's hard enough getting the Kriegsmarine on board as it is.
With the INPF, misschien. They're happy to patrol off the Dutch coast.
That's the only thing that worries you more.
Now you're catching on. Next thing you know we'll be finishing each other's--
Morganas?
That'll do.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Is there any credence to these rumors?

Fields.DialogueText: Still searching. There's too much smoke not to look for fire.

Fields.MenuText: Dear god...

Fields.DialogueText: Now you can see my concern.
Must be something big.
It is. Word is that the Kriegsmarine have been running a brisk business in smuggling. Contraband, currency...
Exactly. The Helleveegen take materiel from any ship they scupper. They're notorious for it.
It wouldn't be *that* strange for a German uniform to show up aboard a Morgana. So why would the Kriegsmarine kapitein claim otherwise?
It confirms what we saw with the patch. Don't you think?
This is all I have to report thus far, Kapitein.
Hmm. Looks like German traffic off of Dutch coasts is up. Well, so's British.
I was looking for a correlation between Helleveege activity and German. There doesn't seem to be one.

Fields.MenuText: Any idea why?

Fields.DialogueText: None yet. With your permission, I would be happy to look into it.
I've been poring over every chart and record of movement I could get my hands on.
Better to have them and not need them, right?
Misschien. Maybe. I'm not used to keeping such an eye on my neighbors because... well, I'm not used to them keeping such an eye on us.
I'm not the only one who's noticed this, either. Willemsoord have been fielding complaints about the Kriegsmarine throwing their weight around.
Well, ask around. I'd do it under color of an INPF inquiry, just to be safe.
I concur.
*ALARM*
I'll start drafting some letters as soon as we get some peace and quiet.
You've been writing letters like it's your job.
It is my job. And I hope I do it well.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Strange.
It could just be a coincidence.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you remember the last time you said that?
Very. I'm glad I don't need to explain.
Alles goed, Kapitein?
Mmhm. I was just thinking...
It'd be nice for us to have dinner together sometime. Just the two of us.
Werkelijk, nu? That sounds like a wonderful idea.
Ohhh? I can see the gears turning in your head, you know. What're you thinking?
Nothing important. I was just... considering our options.
Do you like caviar, Kapitein?

Fields.MenuText: Never had it.
I like it well enough.
Eugh. Can't stand the stuff.

Fields.DialogueText: Good.
... I thought we'd be cooking with Fleet rations.
Mm, a little bird told me you can still get good caviar out of Den Haag.
A metaphorical bird, or...?
It's very salty. Erg lekker. I think you'll enjoy it.
That's fine, Kapitein. You don't have to eat it if you don't want to.
For the safety of my aviary? Let's go with "yes."
Ah. Well, then. I'm looking forward to it.
To the caviar, or--
To having a nice meal with you.
*ALARM*
Let's live long enough to make it happen.
@BATTLE
Mm, that smells good.
If you'd like to pick up a knife, I'd be happy for the help.
What are you making?
I'm falling back on the classics. Bitterballen, fresh mustard, a few cheeses. I wasn't able to get caviar... or creme fraiche... or even a convincing jenever, unfortunately.
Pity. Seems like your little bird found the wrong nest.
Seems like. But we managed to get plenty of good food - *and* I didn't break the bank.

Fields.MenuText: It sure seems like a lot of food.
Thrifty as ever, huh?
I don't care what we're eating, as long as I can eat with you.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah... Flatterer! Here, make yourself useful.
You flatter me, Kapitein. But really, especially without the caviar, it's nothing groundbreaking.
Beyond the bitterballen? Erwtensoep with sausage for the main course, and appeltaart for dessert.
So, what's on the menu?
Always happy to help.
I'm not much for luxury, but everyone deserves a nice meal every now and then.
Sounds hearty.
It will be when we're-
*ALARM*
... Done.
Get up to the deck. I'll get these pans off the stove.
Ja, ja. ...I hope they won't ruin our dinner.
Not on my watch, they won't.
@BATTLE
Let's clean up the stragglers!
Ja, ja! We've got this.
@BATTLE
-- And see, they didn't even ruin dinner. This is delicious.
Dank je wel! I worked hard on it.
You sure did.
You like to cook, and I like to eat. It's like it was meant to be.
You really think so, Kapitein?
Hm? Something wrong? You look so serious.
...Do you really think that the two of us... were meant to meet each other?

Fields.MenuText: I don't know if anyone's 'meant' to meet anyone'...
I knew you were something special from the moment I laid eyes on you.
I don't know, but I can't imagine life without you.

Fields.DialogueText: Ik voel me hetzelfde. You're ... dependable. A good Kapitein.
Kapitein, you flatter me! Was I even awake then?
Mm. It really is difficult to say, isn't it.
Of course you were. You're not just your ship, right?
Thank you. I try to be.
Mm, that's true.
And you succeed.
It really is. ...But it doesn't make this any less special, does it?
I suppose you're right.
What the two of us have here... it really is special. And that scares me.
Really? Why?
I'm coming to trust you, Kapitein. Implicitly. You know what that means, right?
It means something different to everyone.
Yes, but-
Hope I'm not interrupting, Miss De Ruyter.
...Oh no.
Apologies, Kapitein, but the lady insisted. Here's the rapport.
One of your birds came back to its coop?
Yes, Kapitein. And I was very much hoping that this one wouldn't.
What is it? We're in the middle of something--
You've got to be joking.
I wish I were, Kapitein. The ship that was supposed to deliver our caviar was sunk and plundered...
... By *human* agents.
... Kriegsmarine, by the looks of it. Yes.

Fields.MenuText: Why am I not surprised.
This is ludicrous. The OKM would never condone this.
Isn't it in the Germans' best interest to protect the Netherlands?

Fields.DialogueText: It wasn't always this way, Kapitein. We used to be friends on the high seas. But...
... Maybe they're just looking the other way.
Can you imagine the dams bursting? They'd have another coast to deal with overnight.
It makes no goddamn sense.
War is a profitable enterprise. They know it as well as we do.
Profitable or not, this can't be their official doctrine. This is an INFP matter; let me handle it.
... The way you've been handling my commendation?
What?
For the Rotterdam Four. ...Without consulting me and without considering what I might have to say on the matter.
Oh, that. I meant to surprise you.
That's not the point-
Why are you even bringing that up at a time like this?
*ALARM*
Apologies, Kapitein. I lost my temper.
None needed. Let's get to the bridge.
@BATTLE
Ah. I thought I'd find you out here.
You know me too well, Kapitein.
I do. And I worry. ....Writing more letters, huh?
Mm. At times like these, we need allies.
And at times like these, we're least likely to get them.
You can say that again.
... The future of the Netherlands hangs in the balance. And here I am wringing my hands and begging others for help.
Not in so many words, I imagine.
I still have my pride. For all the good it'll do me.

Fields.MenuText: I think it'll do you a lot of good.
Buck up, de Ruyter. This isn't the worst we've faced by a long shot.
You've made a lot of good friends. When push comes to shove, you'll have someone in your corner.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope you're right.
You're right. Of course you're right. These bandits wish they had half the teeth the Helleveegen do.
Now there's a mental image.
I'm struggling to think of anything more I can do.
Well, you're good at struggling, aren't you?
... You're good at connecting with people, De Ruyter.
So good that it feels like it was always meant to be. --They'll come through for you.
Is that really how you-
*ALARM*
How I what?
Never mind that. Let's show these Morganas who has the most teeth.
@BATTLE
You could paper your hull with all these letters.
Mm. My birdies came back.
And what did they tell you?
Ten eerste: the low-lives we've been dealing with weren't just pirates. They were running a protection racket.
... Good grief.
The INFP's been spread thin enough that these pestkoppen thought they could get away with it. Tell everyone they'll keep the Rode Ogen away for a fee...
... And scupper anyone who's lucky enough not to get sunk by Morganas.
Exactly. A nasty little scheme, ja?
Indeed. What were your other discoveries?
Ten tweede: reliable sources tell me that the racket doesn't go all the way to the top. You were right- this isn't OKM doctrine.

Fields.MenuText: I'm always right.
Did your sources tell you anything about OKM doctrine we didn't already know?
Just a few bad apples. That's a relief.

Fields.DialogueText: Smarmy today, Kapitein?
It's what I expected. And hoped for.
Besides a diatribe about her compatriots' unmentionable shore leave habits? No.
So your source is a Belle?
Mm. My birds are literal, Kapiteine.
What was the third thing on your list?
Ah. Ten derde:  I'm told someone's brought it to Raeder's attention.
Already? Your birdies fly fast.
*ALARM*
And Morganas fly faster. Let's dispatch them, Kapitaine.
@BATTLE
You hear the statement from the Koningin today, Kapitein?
Where's she at these days?
Holding out in Den Haag.
I thought the Morganas shelled the palace.
They did. She packed up and moved to the Kurhaus.
Right there on the beach? That's insane.
Objectively. France, Germany, and Britain have all offered her asylum and she isn't having it. Britain least of all.

Fields.MenuText: France has problems of its own.

Fields.DialogueText: Her words exactly.
So what did she say?
Very little... and a lot. She said nobody was in this alone and to seek shelter with friends old and new.
"Do as I say, not as I do," eh?
I hated her for it at first, between you and me. Going to the beach where the sea monsters are.
But if we let the Helleveegen have them, I expect we're as good as dead anyway. I can respect wanting to go out seeing the North Sea.
Might as well fight for it.
... Does she call them-
Not over the radio, she doesn't.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I don't imagine Germany would be a popular choice.

Fields.DialogueText: Not lately, but it ought to blow over if they're serious about the anti-corruption drive.

Fields.MenuText: Why not Britain?

Fields.DialogueText: Really, really long story. I try to ignore it.
Godver... I don't believe this.
In your nest again, de Ruyter? What's eating you?
More letters. It's nothing...
Those look like official orders. I don't think it's nothing.
Ah, I should have taken these to you right away. Het spijt me.
Hey. I don't blame you for needing a moment to think about something distressing.
Simply put? I got a lot of bad news today.
... What'd your birds tell you?
Well, the orders are the biggest piece of it. We've been told, from the top, not to comply with German seizures and forfeitures.
In what universe is that a bad thing?
In the one where civilians are getting these orders, too. They're taking things a bit... literally.
Everyone from bars to brothels is turning German sailors away from the door. Which is... not ideal.
No? I'd have thought you'd be better safe than shaken down.
Well, yes. But we need both their money and their goodwill. If their beer money isn't going to the war effort, and they find Dutch ports unfriendly...
Their Kapiteins won't be happy to protect us when the time comes.
Well. My own "birdies" tell me that the Kriegsmarine's officially pulled back to international waters. They must be trying to sort this out.
So with any luck, you'll be getting German beer money again soon.
Here's to hoping.
It leaves an opening for the Morganas. But at least it's a sign of international cooperation.
Don't make me *laugh*, Kapitein!
... I don't think I've ever heard you sound this bitter.
You would be too, if you'd gotten the letters I've gotten today.
That looks like it's from the Royal Navy.
... I haven't just been corresponding with other Belles, Kapitein.
I've been talking with every boss I could get my hands on. All the way to the top, if I could.
And look at the trash I've gotten.
"We regret to inform you that no ships can be spared, as our own coasts are under the same attack?"
That's from "La Royale." Pff.
Well, I suppose the French are dealing with the same bull we are...
I'd give them a pass, but... look at these.
The Americans are allegedly so tied down in the Pacific they can't spare anyone... the Japanese, ditto-
And the Royal Navy had the unmitigated *gall* to hint that they'd help if we'd let them give Her Majesty asylum.

Fields.MenuText: I'm so sorry.
With allies like these, who needs enemies?
Why am I not surprised?

Fields.DialogueText: I shouldn't have been either.
Right? At least a handful of my correspondents had the grace to apologize.
Maury said she wanted to help but her orders didn't allow it... and Bulldog told me I'd had a "rotten run of luck".
... Well, that's kind of them.
... I wanted to believe that someone would help, if only because we'd become a symbol of something. But.
I think she just wanted to keep me from going to the press.
Nee, nee. Do not *dare* take the blame for this, Kapitein.
... It's sympathy. I wish there was more I could do.
*ALARM*
No sense in sitting around feeling sorry for ourselves, I suppose.
None indeed.
@BATTLE
Talk about a protection racket. At least our piratical friends have the good grace not to pretend that they're doing us a favor.
Writing more letters?
Ja. I see you are too?
Mm, just reports. What about you?
... Letters with condolences.
Sorry to hear it. Widows and orphans?
Mm, and mothers.
That's a big stack.
There's a lot of dead sailors. And even more dead civilians.

Fields.MenuText: That's the last thing we need.
... It's considerate of you to write these yourself.
Haven't their commanding officers already written letters...?

Fields.DialogueText: *How* many did you say-
Too many. Nobody in or out of Haarlem until they finish counting the dead.
And the Helleveegen were sighted off Callantsoog this morning. They're definitely making a play for the Waddenzee. And that means we have to consider the Afsluitdijk to be at risk.
It is. We won't go down without a fight, but that means losing good people.
Civilians don't have those.
... It feels like my duty.
And you're letting thir families know what happened.
I'm a symbol. Most of these people will never see me.
But they need to know ... someone cares.
Maybe you care too much.
Mm. This is the calm before the storm. If I don't keep busy, I'll start thinking.
... And as much as I try, so many of these letters are the same. You know?
Yep. Losing the dike and seeing the dramatic return of the Zuiderzee would be pretty much the last thing we need.
I wish I could say that was the case. But my birdies have given me even worse news.
... Worse than the Morganas?
*ALARM*
Godver! You summoned them.
Tell me about this news.
After we've fought them off.
@BATTLE
So about that news-
Wees alsjeblieft stil.
Ah. Sorry, I'll be quiet. Orders over the radio?
Ja. One moment.
... I'm afraid you're going to have to see it, rather than hear it.
Do you remember the rumours I heard, about Kriegsmarine ships kidnapping sailors?
Yes, but... you didn't seem to put much stock in them.
The sailors telling them were civilians or recent civilians. I assumed they'd gotten hit by Morganas and were ashamed to admit it.

Fields.MenuText: There's no shame in that.
I'd be lying too, honestly.
...But we've got a credible report now?

Fields.DialogueText: Mm. From a German coal ship.
Most civilians still think Morganas are... mindless. Destructive the way a typhoon or a hurricane are destructive.
Then you understand why we weren't likely to believe them.
Ah, that's fair.  ...Goodness knows how much effort's gone into getting them to think that.
*This* report came from an experienced Kapitein, and one we've traded with often.
They were definitely human ships. Flying German flags. But--
So it's our bad apples.
You could say that, but-
*ALARM*
Morganas to port?
And human enemies to starboard. Look alive, everyone!
@BATTLE
There's two fleets out there... and they're both flying German flags.
Look closer, Kapitein. I wish I had my telescope right now...
... Wait a second. What on earth-
You see why I was angry.
... Those are Royal Navy.
*Ja*. Flying German colors. And press-ganging Dutch citizens.

Fields.MenuText: That's perfidy. They should be ashamed.
You're a neutral country! Why on earth would they--
No surprise, considering how shabbily they've treated you.

Fields.DialogueText: They've forgotten there are places where the sun sets.
I wish I had the luxury of surprise.
They won't be until we shell them.
So who's the other German fleet?
It looks to be the genuine Kriegsmarine. They're engaging now.
Oh, son of a-
Kapitein? One thing at a time - the Morganas brought friends.
... Fine. Prioritize the non-human problems.
For all the good that will do us.
@BATTLE
Somebody get me radio contact with the fake Germans before this gets any worse! Make it clear that on behalf of the League of Nations, the INPF, and some very powerful Belles, I'm calling an end to-
De Ruyter, what this could do to the Neutrality Fleet-
We can't fix it if we're dead, Kapitein.
The fake German ships are done for. Idiots.
Let's mop up the rest of these Helleveegen, then.
@BATTLE
So, what you're telling me is... there were *two* barrels of bad apples.
Well, calling them "barrels" is a bit overblown. It was a few kapiteins on both sides.
The Kriegsmarine "apples" really were running a protection racket. But that was *all* they were doing.
Their ringleader said - according to one of my birds - that they were just taking what we owed them, and nothing more.
Sure they were. What about the *other* set?
... The kidnappings? Het is erg jammer.
They were, allegedly, a few rogue officers of the Royal Navy. They said they were just "recruiting" sailors, because they'd taken casualties.
But people are lining up to volunteer. For real.
But this is a classic British move, no? Getting men blackout drunk so that they could be pushed aboard ships.
The rogue Royal Navy kapitein said he thought we'd be siding with the Axis any day now. That there was no sense pretending we wouldn't.

Fields.MenuText: A self-fulfilling prophecy.
I'm amazed he thought he could get away with it.
So, what, he pretends to be Axis to get you to side with them?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure *what* he was planning. Or *if*.
He's lucky we've faced perfidy at every turn.
What he thought is irrelevant. We've caught him in the act.
These are the most cockamamie schemes I've had to deal with...
... I'm just glad it's over.
... I'm sorry, Kapitein. The war's exhausting enough without having to deal with... all this.
You're not wrong. So... now you go back to writing letters?
Yes. But now I'll wonder even more if they're doing anything at all.
For *you*. Perhaps not so much for ships without our prestige.
... Right. And given that ships' officers were decimated when all this started, God only knows what kind of desperate idiots assumed command in some of these cases.
Not just the British. And it hasn't really been in vogue this century. Until now, I guess.
Maybe it's over for *you*. I need to spend a couple of days getting the Kriegsmarine and the Royal Navy to agree to the whole "bad apples on both sides" hypothesis.
Mail call, de Ruyter! You've got a stack a mile high today.
Oh, my, you weren't joking. That's... quite a few things.
It'll take you hours to open them all, huh?
It'll keep my mind off my troubles, that's for sure.
Well, I brought them to your cabin, so no need to carry them.
Kind of you.
Did you touch my hand just now on purpose?

Fields.MenuText: What? No.
What would you say if I did?
I'll gladly do it again.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah. Um. Well.
Ah. Kapitein, I--
... Oh. Well.
I'd be. Flattered, Kapitein.
Is that a hint of disappointment?
... If you're happy with it, of course.
Very.
That's good to hear.
Yes.
Next you'll tell me you want to. Hold my hand.
Mmm. If you like.
*ALARM*
Ah, well. Here's something I know how to handle.
You don't know how to handle hand-holding?
Not in the slightest.
@BATTLE
But we don't have time to talk about that right now.
Still opening your mail?
It's a very big stack, Kapitein. I haven't even gotten through the packages yet.
You're opening those before the official mail?
The orders will keep. The packages might go stale.
Ah. A *lot* of people have sent you pastries, huh?
Mm. Some of them are just... I suppose you'd call them fans?
... It's better than the letters from... people I wrote to the other day. You know the ones.
The letters of condolence?
They're evenly split between grieving thanks and... vitriol.

Fields.MenuText: I'm surprised people even write back.
It makes sense. You're an easy target.
...Think about the people who believe in you, and ignore the rest?

Fields.DialogueText: It's what I try to do, Kapitein.
An easier target than whoever gave the orders, that's for sure.
I'm not. At least not at the angry ones.
... Is there anything I can do to help?
Just sit with me? It's a little overwhelming.
Of course. Anything for you, de Ruyter.
*ALARM*
Well. I could use a break.
It could be more relaxing.
Oh, certainly.
@BATTLE
You've gotten to your official mail?
And my newspaper backlog, yes. I read them at the same time.
Literally? Or metaphorically?
Depends on the day.
Well, which is it today?
Reading many different verses of the same song.
"This was a rogue agent, we had no idea this was happening." Deny, disavow, destroy any evidence.

Fields.MenuText: It's better than a lot of the alternatives.
Ah. Politics.
Maybe they're telling the truth.

Fields.DialogueText: I like it as little as you do, Kapitein. But this is the world we live in.
"Understanding it" and "liking it" are two different animals.
... You can't be *that* naiive, Kapitein.
It is.
When it comes to the people who are looking for a reason to invade? Some *public* naiivety is a good thing.
... As long as it's only public.
... The British say they're sending some ships to control Morgana advances from the Channel. And the Germans offered to station a few of their girls from Texel to Skagerrak.
Mighty generous of them. That's their idea of an apology?
Seems so. But I can't help but wonder.
Is it an apology, or another threat?
*ALARM*
The future can wait til the future. The Morganas are a threat *now*.
Begrepen, kapitein. Uitgaan.
@BATTLE
You don't approve?
That's a lot of papers even for you.
Ah, Kapitein! Sorry, I didn't see you there.
It's fine. What are you doing? It looks like you're trying to decipher some kind of code.
That's exactly what I'm doing.
Whose code?
Mm. My correspondents and I have each set up our own set.
Sounds like a lot of work. A different code for everyone you write to?
Every Belle. But I can assure you, the effort's worth it.

Fields.MenuText: Anything to keep your cards to your chest, huh?
Trying to stop the Morganas from reading your mail?
It sounds like a *lot* of effort. Hope it's worth it.

Fields.DialogueText: I wouldn't go to the effort if it wasn't.
Yes, and more.
Agreed. But that's not the only reason.
Think about it. It's true: if we write our letters in code, it makes it more difficult for Morganas to mimic them.
But it also makes security easier for my friends who are fighting the land war.
How do you figure?
Well, let me give you an example. I'm pen pals with both Admiral Graf Spee and Émile Bertin.
Spee's German. Bertin's French. Both of them have more interests than the land war. But they'll likely give their commanding officers any intel they can.
... What happens if I mix up the envelopes? If I send Spee Bertin's letter, and Bertin Spee's?
Unfortunately for me, I know exactly where you're coming from. You accidentally gave them intel that they should never have had.
Ja precies. And I might be putting one- or both- of them into danger.
It makes sense that you would want to avoid that. Neutrality, and all.
Exactly. So I have a different code for each of my birds. We put them together in the early days, no two are alike.
So who's that one from?
Well, I haven't finished decoding them-
*ALARM*
So I'll tell you when I have.
@BATTLE
Is that steam coming out of your ears, or are you just happy to see me?
Ah. Don't start. -Alsjeblieft.
Fair. You seem flustered.
Not for that reason. I'm *annoyed*. And I'm trying to figure out a defense.
Against what?
A couple of my German pen friends have... we've discussed the matter of the "bad apples."
This one's from ... "Strindberg"?
Mmm.
Is there a Belle by that name?
Nee, dat is er niet. It's a code name.
She sent me a lovely, chatty letter, and told me that she'd heard things "went well"...
... and then "Brunhilde" sent me this.
... Is that a censored military tribunal report?
Mm. Two OKM captains tried for Kriegsverrat. And see, this note here.
It's in German... wait, don't tell me...
"We took out our trash. Can your other neighbors say the same"?
I don't know how to feel about this, Kapitein. Of course I'll be cordial to them both, but-

Fields.MenuText: Do you really need to be cordial?
Do you need to feel anything about it?
Do you need a hug?

Fields.DialogueText: I'd like one, but this is part of my job. I should be able to handle it.
No, I suppose not. This is part of my job.
Of course I do! This is part of my job.
You take your job very seriously.
*ALARM*
And there are very good reasons why.
Let's engage those "reasons," then.
@BATTLE
But the air of superiority grates on you.
Ja precies. One might even call it smugness.
Are you feeling all right? You're in your nest again.
Old habits die hard, don't they?
Suppose so.
Well.
Natuurlijk.
Mmm. The moon's bright tonight.
It really is.
What are you looking at me like that for?
Like what?
The moon's that way.
Ah. I'm being silly, aren't I...
A little.
...I just don't understand you, Kapitein.

Fields.MenuText: What's not to understand? I'm an open book.
Maybe you like my air of mystery.
Sometimes I don't understand me either.

Fields.DialogueText: They say it's only the wise man who knows himself...
I like your compassion. But I don't understand why you have it.
That's the thing I don't understand.
... Everyone else has an angle. There's something they want from me, and they need my goodwill to get it.
But you... I don't know what it is you want from me.
I like you. I want you to be happy.
... You want me to be happy so badly that you'll waste political capital on... trivial things. Just to make me happy.
... The commendation?
Ja.... And, under better circumstances, it would have made me happy. I'm... touched that you care.
... It wasn't in my best interests. Or yours. But you did it anyway. Because you thought it would make me happy.
... I thought it was in your best interests. I wanted to surprise you. But I should have asked you first. We're a team.
We are. And that's... I really don't know how you did it, Kapitein.
Even with that oversight... I still feel like I can trust you.
It's enough to make you believe in destiny.
Can I sit with you?
... Can I hold your hand now?
